name: cp
desc: The cp command is a command-line tool used to copy files and directories in Linux and Unix systems. It can copy a file or directory from one location to another, and can also rename, modify permissions, and so on for the copied file or directory.

-r.name: Copy directories and their contents recursively.

-a.name: Preserve all attributes when copying files and directories, including owner, group, and permissions.

-f.name: Force copy, overwriting the target file if it already exists.

-i.name: Interactive copy, prompting the user to confirm before overwriting the target file.

-l.name: Copy symbolic link files themselves, rather than their contents.

-n.name: Do not copy if the target file already exists.

-p.name: Preserve the attributes of the source file, including owner, group, and time.

-s.name: Create symbolic link files instead of copying files.

-u.name: Only copy files that are newer or do not exist in the target file.

-x.name: Do not cross file system boundaries during copying, only copy within the same file system.

content:
Example

  • cp file.txt file_backup.txt, copy file.txt to file_backup.txt, and overwrite it if file_backup.txt already exists.
  • cp -r dir1 dir2, copy directory dir1 to dir2, including all subdirectories and files within it.
  • cp -u file.txt dir/, copy file.txt to directory dir/. Do not copy it if a newer version of file.txt already exists in dir/.
  • cp -a dir1/ dir2/, copy directory dir1/ to dir2/, and preserve all metadata.
  • cp -s file.txt symlink, create a symbolic link named symlink in the current directory, pointing to file.txt.
